the politics of science and what
determines what we want to study what we

first I want to thank the people who

that I'm going to show you today our
funders always very grateful to them and

explores the frontiers of consciousness
and translates what we learn in to

right now it's really fascinating we did
we sponsored a bibliography of all of

now there are between eight and nine

at every major university in the country
they would have thought that was
really futuristic idea so we've learned

the point that number one we know a lot
about how now meditation even practicing
as little as twenty minutes a day for
eight weeks not only changes the

to stimuli but also at a resting state
but fascinatingly even the structure of
our brain which I think prior to this
kind of research we thought was a lot
more static it turns out we can enhance
the thickness of our cortical matter
increased gray matter all kinds of
changes in our brains just through where
we place our attention just through
where we place our attention changing
the structure of our brain we've also
looked at meditation and its effects on
our hormonal and biochemical systems in
the brain the stress hormones on our
immunity and how it helps us respond to
intruding germs so there's just an
enormous amount of excellent research
looking at again which what really
interests me is just directing your
mental attention toward your breathing
or toward your body for 20 minutes a day
or for you know maybe maybe even over
years changes all of these psycho
physiological aspects of your being one
of the most exciting areas of research
is probably that not only is it
affecting our brains and our bodies and
our bio chemicals it may even be
affecting the way our genes are
expressed we are seeing some interesting
changes in gene expression as a result
of meditation and my colleague Elissa
EPEL is here who's also been looking at
the possibility that not only is it
affecting gene expression but it may be
that we can use meditation to counteract
some of the effects of stress on
telomere shortening which is the way
that cells are told when they'll die so
the idea that we can just change our
attention and it changes our body is
amazing
it also changes our mind multiple
studies now looking at different types
of meditation enhancing psychological
well-being emotion regulation depression
anxiety attention concentration
cognitive flexibility a numerous
psychological variables seem to respond
to meditation and so when you look at
the field of meditation research at the
moment there's a very large emphasis on
how it affects our brain in our body
there's maybe next how does it affect
our mind there's a little tiny bit on
how it affects our relationships with
other people and with the world around
us there's a tiny bit of research on how
meditation affects what I'm calling our
spirit and what I mean by that is our
sense of purpose and meaning and hope
our general orientation to the world and
even a smaller amount on how it affects
sort of what you might call a collective
well-being of society and the planet so
this is how we emphasize things now I'd
like to suggest in this talk that in
fact it is important what meditation
does to the body but it may be even more
important what it does to the mind if
you look at what is causing the most
human suffering on our planet right now
some of it is disease but much of it if
we're looking at war hunger poverty
destruction of resources these are
things that actually are happening in
the human mind it may be more important
for us to look at how meditation might
impact the way we look at the world and
then how we behave in response to what
we find in it it may even be more
important how meditation affects our
relationships with one another and our
relationships with the environment
around us and with the planet and I'd
propose it might even be even more
important to look at how it instills
meaning hope purpose and a life
orientation among all of us at our
individual level and at our collective
level and yet those aspects of
meditation
our understudied so it's almost like

very little research on meditation in

the impact of meditating or practicing

on our relationships one of the studies

what happens when we teach pregnant

their breathing toward their bodies we

most of us go meditate in groups at some

well most people would say there's

this is an aspect of work that kind of
